The values expressed in words per minute indicate the speed with which the patient speaks. Very high values suddenly could be associated with manic episodes

This metric measured in words per minute quantifies the speed of the patients' speech.</br> Several studies show that psychotic states due to schizophrenia or manic states of bipolarity could increase the speed of speech. Also anxiety states could alter this metric.

• Tan, EJ, Thomas, N., & Rossell, SL (2014). Speech disturbances and quality of life in schizophrenia: Differential impacts on functioning and life satisfaction. Comprehensive psychiatry, 55 (3), 693-698.
  • Dunayevich, E., & Keck, PE (2000). Prevalence and description of psychotic features in bipolar mania. Current psychiatry reports, 2 (4), 286-290.
  • DelBello, MP (2018). A risk calculator for bipolar disorder in youth: improving the odds for personalized prevention and early intervention ?. Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, 57 (10), 725-727.
The median duration of silences. Longer silences could be associated with pathologies such as depression and schizophrenia. Sudden shorter silences could be associated with hypomanic episodes

Various studies have shown that silences between expressions can be useful to characterize pathologies. In particular, some studies show that patients with schizophrenia show higher values in the duration of silences as well as in the number of silences. Also this effect occurs for patients with depression.

• Rapcan, V., D'Arcy, S., Yeap, S., Afzal, N., Thakore, J., & Reilly, RB (2010). Acoustic and temporal analysis of speech: A potential biomarker for schizophrenia. Medical engineering & physics, 32 (9), 1074-1079.
  • Alpert, M., Pouget, ER, & Silva, RR (2001). Reflections of depression in acoustic measures of the patient's speech. Journal of affective disorders, 66 (1), 59-69.
  • Clemmer, EJ. Psycholinguistic aspects of pauses and temporal patterns in schizophrenic speech. Journal of Psycholinguistic Research, 9 (2), 161-185.
A greater number of silences per word could be associated with pathologies such as schizophrenia or depression. Fewer silences could be associated with hypomanic episodes.

The number of silences per word is a way to control how the silence times are distributed in the speech. A greater number of silences could be associated with pathologies such as schizophrenia or depression. Fewer silences could be associated with hypomanic episodes.

• Rapcan, V., D'Arcy, S., Yeap, S., Afzal, N., Thakore, J., & Reilly, RB (2010). Acoustic and temporal analysis of speech: A potential biomarker for schizophrenia. Medical engineering & physics, 32 (9), 1074-1079.
  • Alpert, M., Pouget, ER, & Silva, RR (2001). Reflections of depression in acoustic measures of the patient's speech. Journal of affective disorders, 66 (1), 59-69.
  • Clemmer, EJ. Psycholinguistic aspects of pauses and temporal patterns in schizophrenic speech. Journal of Psycholinguistic Research, 9 (2), 161-185.
Analysis of the patient's attitude when recording the story according to the positivity, negativity or neutrality of the speech
Values close to -1 express negativity, 0 neutrality and 1 positivity. Some works associate negative values of expressiveness with depressive pictures.

Emotional valence is a measure that quantifies the emotionality of the story. Going from stories with a negative evaluation (value -1), through stories with a neutral evaluation (value 0) and stories with a positive evaluation (value 1). Some works associate negative values of expressiveness with depressive pictures. Other work uses emotional valence to predict whether or not participants will respond to treatment

• Denny, EB, & Hunt, RR (1992). Affective valence and memory in depression: dissociation of recall and fragment completion. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 101 (3), 575.
  • Carrillo, F., Sigman, M., Slezak, DF, Ashton, P., Fitzgerald, L., Stroud, J., ... & Carhart-Harris, RL (2018). Natural speech algorithm applied to baseline interview data can predict which patients will respond to psilocybin for treatment-resistant depression. Journal of affective disorders, 230, 84-86.
Values close to 0 express zero emotionality, higher values express more emotionality.

The emotional magnitude provides information regarding how much emotional content a story has regardless of its valence.
Stories with no emotional expression have a neutral valence (value 0) as do stories that express a lot of positive and negative emotionality. To correct this, this measure is used because in these examples, the story with no emotional expression has 0 magnitude while the other, with zero emotional valence but with a lot of positive and negative expression, has a high emotional magnitude value.

• Denny, EB, & Hunt, RR (1992). Affective valence and memory in depression: dissociation of recall and fragment completion. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 101 (3), 575.
  • Carrillo, F., Sigman, M., Slezak, DF, Ashton, P., Fitzgerald, L., Stroud, J., ... & Carhart-Harris, RL (2018). Natural speech algorithm applied to baseline interview data can predict which patients will respond to psilocybin for treatment-resistant depression. Journal of affective disorders, 230, 84-86.

The clarity of the story measures how simple the structure of the story is. The easy-to-interpret stories have values close to 100 (up to 130) while the confusing stories are close to 0 and even take negative values.

The clarity of the story measures how simple its structure is, taking into account the number of words per sentence, the length of the words, the number of syllables, etc. This measure ranges from minus infinity to 130. The easy-to-interpret stories have values close to 100 while the complex and confusing ones close to 0 and even take negative values.
Different works relate the clarity of thought is affected in different with pathologies. For example, there is some evidence that in the onset of psychosis due to schizophrenia, language deteriorates, generating productions that are more confusing and difficult to interpret.

When archiving a patient, it will be disabled for all use, this includes:

  • The patient will no longer appear in the patient list.
  • You will no longer be able to access the patient's medical record.
  • You will no longer be able to see the patient scales and protocols.
  • Patient events will not appear on the calendar.

Either way, all archived patients can be unarchived from the list of archived patients on the home page.

The questionnaire was designed to investigate psychotic experiences throughout life in the general population. For this scale, no cut-off points were defined that determine the presence of psychosis because it was thought based on symptomatic dimensions, and not in relation to categorical diagnoses.

The symptoms evaluated correspond to the DSM-IV criteria. This instrument helps to diagnose depression, determine the severity of the disorder, and monitor treatment.

It consists of 9 items that can be scored between 0 and 3 according to the frequency with which the symptoms occurred.

Investigate a range of symptoms linked to depression and anxiety. The total score on the scale can indicate the risk of suffering psychological distress but does not specify whether it is one or the other disorder.

It consists of 10 items with a five-point Likert-type response format : always, many times, sometimes, a few times and never

It allows you to quickly detect the presence of a clinically significant anxiety disorder.

It consists of 7 items that are scored between 0 and 3 according to the frequency with which the symptoms occurred

• Thomas, P., Leudar, I., Newby, D., & Johnston, M. (1993). Syntactic processing and written language output in first onset psychosis. Journal of communication disorders, 26 (4), 209-230.
  • Barch, DM, & Berenbaum, H. (1997). The effect of language production manipulations on negative thought disorder and discourse coherence disturbances in schizophrenia. Psychiatry Research, 71 (2), 115-127.
Low values of the main tone are associated with features present in depressive conditions.

Various studies have studied the effect of the fundamental tone of speech (pitch) with depressive features associating low values of the fundamental tone with high values of expression of depressive symptoms.
Some studies also find pitch levels informative to predict first psychotic episodes.

• Wang, J., Zhang, L., Liu, T., Pan, W., Hu, B., & Zhu, T. (2019). Acoustic differences between healthy and depressed people: a cross-situation study. BMC psychiatry, 19 (1), 1-12.
  • S. Scherer, GM Lucas, J. Gratch, A. Rizzo and LP Morency, 'Self-Reported Symptoms of Depression and PTSD Are Associated with Reduced Vowel Space in Screening Interviews', IEEE Trans. Affect. Comput., 2016
  • Agurto, C., Pietrowicz, M., Norel, R., Eyigoz, EK, Stanislawski, E., Cecchi, G., & Corcoran, C. (2020, July). Analyzing acoustic and prosodic fluctuations in free speech to predict psychosis onset in high-risk youths. In 2020 42nd Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine & Biology Society (EMBC) (pp. 5575-5579). IEEE.
The decrease in the variation in the tone of speech may be related to features present in depressive pictures.

Various studies have studied the effect on the variations of the fundamental tone of speech (pitch) with depressive features, associating a low variation of the fundamental tone with high values on different depression scales.
Some studies also find pitch variations informative to predict first psychotic episodes.

• Wang, J., Zhang, L., Liu, T., Pan, W., Hu, B., & Zhu, T. (2019). Acoustic differences between healthy and depressed people: a cross-situation study. BMC psychiatry, 19 (1), 1-12.
  • Cannizzaro, M., Harel, B., Reilly, N., Chappell, P., & Snyder, PJ (2004). Voice acoustical measurement of the severity of major depression. Brain and cognition, 56 (1), 30-35.
  • Horwitz, R., Quatieri, TF, Helfer, BS, Yu, B., Williamson, JR, & Mundt, J. (2013, May). On the relative importance of vocal source, system, and prosody in human depression. In 2013 IEEE International Conference on Body Sensor Networks (pp. 1-6). IEEE.
  • S. Scherer, GM Lucas, J. Gratch, A. Rizzo and LP Morency, 'Self-Reported Symptoms of Depression and PTSD Are Associated with Reduced Vowel Space in Screening Interviews', IEEE Trans. Affect. Comput., 2016.

The questionnaire was designed to investigate psychotic experiences throughout life in the general population. For this scale, no cut-off points were defined that determine the presence of psychosis because it was thought based on symptomatic dimensions, and not in relation to categorical diagnoses.

It consists of 10 items with a five-point Likert-type response format: always, many times, sometimes, rarely and never. The “never” response is assigned a scalar value of 1 and the “always” response, 5 points.

The sum of the scores has a minimum of 10 and a maximum of 50.

The instrument ranges have four levels:

  • Low risk of suffering from psychological distress (10-15 points)
  • Moderate risk of suffering from psychological distress (16-21 points)
  • High risk of suffering from psychological distress (22- 29 points)
  • Very high risk of suffering from psychological distress (30-50 points)
References:
  • Andrews, G., & Slade, T. (2001). Interpreting scores on the Kessler psychological distress scale (K10). Australian and New Zealand journal of public health, 25 (6), 494-497.
There is already a user with this email

21-item self-administered scale. In each of these, the person has to choose, among a set of 4 alternatives ordered from least to greatest severity, the phrase that best describes their state during the last two weeks including the day they complete the instrument.

Each item is valued from 0 to 3 points depending on the chosen alternative and, after directly adding the score of each item, a total score can be obtained that varies from 0 to 63

  • No depression: indicates (score less than 14) indicates minimal or no depressive symptoms
  • Mild: indicates mild levels of depressive symptoms (score 14 to 19)
  • Moderate: indicates moderate levels of depressive symptoms (score 20 to 28)
  • Severe: indicates severe levels of depressive symptoms (score 29 and up)

It consists of 9 items that are scored on a 4-point scale: 0 = 'never', 1 = 'some days', 2 = 'more than half of the days' and 3 = 'almost every day'

The points are added, resulting in a total score between 0 and 27 that indicates the severity of the depressive symptoms and suggests the need for treatment:

  • Minimal depression. The patient may not need treatment to combat depression (0-4 points)
  • Mild depression The use of clinical judgment regarding treatment is suggested based on the duration of symptoms and the patient's functional disorder (5-9 points)
  • Moderate depression The use of clinical judgment regarding treatment is suggested based on the duration of symptoms and the patient's functional disorder (10-14 points).
  • Moderately severe depression. Treatment for depression with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or a combination of treatments is warranted (15-20 points)
  • Severe depression Treatment for depression with antidepressants, psychotherapy, or a combination of treatments is warranted (20-27 points)
Additionally, a question is added to quantify the difficulty caused by the problems reported in previous questions.

References:
  • Kroenke, K., Spitzer, RL, & Williams, JB (2001). The PHQ ‐ 9: validity of a brief depression severity measure. Journal of general internal medicine, 16 (9), 606-613.

  • Mild depression The use of clinical judgment regarding treatment is suggested based on the duration of symptoms and the patient's functional disorder (5-9 points)

  • Kroenke, K., Spitzer, RL, & Williams, JB (2001). The PHQ ‐ 9: validity of a brief depression severity measure. Journal of general internal medicine, 16 (9), 606-613.

It consists of 7 items that are scored on a 4-point scale: 0 = 'never', 1 = 'some days', 2 = 'more than half of the days' and 3 = 'almost every day'.

The points are added together, resulting in a total score between 0 and 21 indicating the severity of the anxiety symptoms:

  • No symptoms of anxiety (0-4)
  • Mild anxiety symptoms (5-9)
  • Moderate anxiety symptoms (10-14)
  • Severe anxiety symptoms (15-21)
References:
  • Spitzer, RL, Kroenke, K., Williams, JB, & Löwe, B. (2006). A brief measure for assessing generalized anxiety disorder: the GAD-7. Archives of internal medicine, 166 (10), 1092-1097.
